SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to raise in the Parliament the future of the automotive parts industry in Australia. I have sought the permission of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) to incorporate in Hansard a letter I received from one of my constituents, the Honourable J. S. Thompson, A.M., M.L.C., who is State Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia. Mr Thompson has spent most of his adult life working for the employees in the vehicle building industry and for the industry itself, and he and his union are most concerned about the turn of events that is occurring at present in the vehicle building industry in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a recent letter I received from Mr Thompson.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Dear Leo,
As you are no doubt aware, the Federal Government will in the near future bring down a Plan on assistance to the Passenger Motor Industry Post 1984.

In the view of the above Union this decision will be one of the most important decisions which the Government has taken as it will have a major effect upon very large sections of Australia's Secondary Industry.

We believe it is most important that all members of the National Parliament are fully aware of the ramifications of any decision which would have the effect of winding down either the manufacturing and assembly section of the Industry or the vehicle component part manufacturing industry.

We are also perturbed at a booklet, produced by General Motors Holden setting out their views on what assistance should be given to the motor vehicle industry after 1984, which was recently distributed to all members of the National Parliament. We believe this booklet portrays a most biased view and one which if implemented, could cause serious problems to major sections of our nation's manufacturing industry.
We believe that what is good for General Motors Holden may not necessarily be good for Australia.

All members should be fully aware that General Motors Holden are part of a global enterprise, and all their views are obviously in favour of the best deal possible for General Motors Holden on a world-wide basis, irrespective of what occurs in the various host countries in which that Company operates.

We find it difficult to reconcile earlier statements in the booklet of how concerned General Motors Holden are that many thousands of jobs will be lost if quotas are lowered or some protection is removed, and further on the booklet makes very strong representation that the export credit programmes be increased.

The Company is obviously aware that the present agreed 5 per cent Export Credit Post 1982, rising to 7 1/2 per cent, will obviously cause the closure of many Australian companies engaged in component manufacture. This is evidenced in their booklet where, on Page 15, they state that around 25 per cent of their existing component part suppliers will be withdrawing from the motor vehicle industry over the next 3 or 4 years even under the existing current conditions.
Our Union believes that many members of Parliament are not aware of how the 85% Local Content is arrived at.

It should not be considered that 85 per cent Local Content means that 85 per cent of the component parts used in building a motor vehicle in Australia are of Australian origin. This is a grave distortion of what is the actual Local Content.
The computing of the 85 per cent Local Content is made up in the following way.
1. Approximately 60 per cent of local content is earned by purely assembling the vehicle in Australia irrespective of the country of origin of the parts used in the assembly of the motor vehicle.
2. If we include the use of Australian manufactured glass, trim (upholstery), tyres, battery, paint, etc., this then takes us to an allowance of approximately 64 per cent Australian content.
3. If we include an engine made in Australia as part of the motor vehicle, we are then credited with building a vehicle with in excess of 70 per cent Australian content.

Under the existing plans after 1984 with the Export Credit Scheme, any Company including General Motors Holden will be allowed for effective purposes to drop the Australian content from 85 per cent to 77 1/2 per cent.

This clearly means that the required componentry to be built in Australia will be extremely limited, and if General Motors Holden's request to the Federal Government to increase the degree of Export Credits if acceded to, it will have the effect of allowing that Company to use vast quantities of imported component parts including transmissions and would deal a severe blow to huge sections of the Australian component part industry.
The importance of the component part industry should not be underestimated.
Currently at least 24,000 people are engaged in this section of industry producing component parts valued at approximately $800 million.

With the implementation of the existing Export Facilitation Policy by 1984 only 16,400 people will be left in the industry and they will be producing component parts which will have dropped in value to $600 million.
If Export Facilitation is increased post 1984 from 7 1/2 per cent to 10 per cent the workforce will then drop to 7,000 people and the value of their production will drop to $325 million.

This is one reason why we find it so difficult to reconcile General Motors Holden's statements on how perturbed they are at the job losses which will occur if some protection is removed from the industry, and at the same time they are calling for a policy of major increases in the Export Facilitation Scheme which, if granted, will cause dramatic losses to both companies and their workforces engaged in Australia's component part manufacturing industry.
To illustrate a point, General Motors Holden plans to export more than 200,000 engines in 1982 for which they will be granted export credits to bring into this country component parts duty free.

At this stage no accurate figures have been produced by General Motors Holden on what they will be charging for each engine which they export. There is no doubt, however, that the amount of money they will earn under the Export Credit Plan will be of a huge magnitude and allow them to import into Australia a vast range of componentry duty free.
It therefore, should clearly be seen that any increase in the percentage allowance for export credits will deal a very severe blow to our component part manufacturing industry.

I write to you not only as the Secretary of our Union closely associated with the Australian Motor Industry, but as a person deeply concerned at the future of much of our country's Secondary Manufacturing Industry.
I believe it is vital that under no circumstances should we allow any extension of the Export Credit/Facilitation Scheme.

I am aware that both the existing and proposed Plans may appear complicated for people not in the Industry. If I can assist in any way in the future, in explaining the ramifications of changes in these Plans, please do not hesitate to contact me. If necessary, I am prepared to speak to any group of Parliamentarians irrespective of Party that desire any further assistance on clarifying any proposal for future Plans for the Australian motor vehicle industry.
Thanking you.
Yours faithfully Hon. J. S. THOMPSON, A.M., M.L.C., SECRETARY

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Thompson points out in his letter that one of the most important things which will occur if the Government's post-1984 program for the Australian car manufacturing industry occurs is that, with the implementation of the existing export facilitation policy by 1984, only 16,400 people will be left in the automotive parts industry and the amount of production by that industry will be reduced from $800m this year to approximately $600m then. I believe that that would be a very detrimental thing. The parts industry provides a vast range of employment for people in my electorate and in adjoining electorates. It also provides a great deal of high technology in Australia. Companies such as TRW Products Ltd, Girlock Ltd, and a number of other smaller suppliers of material, are right in the forefront of technological advances in this country. If the Government's proposals go forward, the activities of many of those companies will be put very much in jeopardy. I think that that would be very much to the detriment of Australian industry and the building up of a base of skills in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent weeks in this Parliament we have seen the Government's attempts to curtail the activities of Telecom Australia, which employs a wide range of highly skilled technical staff. The attack on the vehicle industry is somewhat the same thing. The important point Mr Thompson makes in his letter is that members of Parliament and the general public should not get carried away with the program being put forward by General Motors-Holden's, whose whole idea is to increase its share of the car market in this country and to ensure that by a back-door method we will not have viable parts and automotive industries. I think it is very important for the Parliament to take account of that. While many people would think that allowing the present manufacturers to get larger will protect the Australian car industry, unfortunately, as Mr Thompson quite lucidly points out in his letter, that is not the case.

I hope that the Parliament will take note of the points put forward by Mr Thompson on behalf of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation and the people employed in the vehicle building and parts manufacturing industries. We should not be seduced by the quite extensive arguments put forward by major manufacturers that we should increase their chances of becoming involved in the world car. This would relegate the Australian parts industry and many jobs in the vehicle building industry in Australia to oblivion. I know that many apologists for that proposal on the other side of the House will probably stand up and put their point of view. I can see that some of those apologists are about to rise very quickly. They should be warned to look at the effect such a course would have on employment and on the level of skill in this country. In my view, if we destroy the skill base of Australia we will sell out the right of Australian industry to have its chance to compete on world markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on a matter arising out of the recent case of the Romanian soccer player, Mr Viscreanu. I do not want to comment particularly on the gentleman himself because the Determination of Refugee Status Committee has made a determination in his case and his future is presently the subject of consideration and further discussions. However, I do want to comment on the type of activity which led this gentleman to defect from the visiting soccer team. I put to the House the point of view that it is not to the advantage of Australia or of people in Mr Viscreanu's position for groups such as migrant groups in Australia to seek to entice people in visiting soccer teams, cultural organisations, or whatever they may be to defect and seek refuge in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand much of the background of many of the people who comprise the migrant groups I have in mind. Many of them have come from communist countries. They have suffered persecution. They have found a new and free life in Australia and are keen to see others share that life. I put it to them that there are dangers in seeking to entice members of sporting teams, cultural groups, scientific exchange groups, to defect in the way that we have seen recently.

The first danger I see is that visits from such groups will cease fairly soon if it becomes a practice for people in Australia to entice visitors to defect from their sporting team or whatever. Secondly, it will become harder for Australia to process genuine family reunion cases, genuine humanitarian cases of reunions between members of families from East European countries, for example, if it becomes known that we encourage or at least turn a blind eye to the activities of people who encourage visitors to defect. It is quite likely that the authorities in those countries will become even harder than they are at present in dealing with applications, which as members of parliament we handle from time to time, to bring about genuine family reunions between people in Australia and their relatives in East European countries.

Thirdly, such activities place the individuals concerned and their families in a very difficult position. No one in a migrant group in Australia is able to guarantee to a visiting sportsman or dancer or scientific adviser that he will obtain permanent residence in Australia. The case has to be examined after the person defects, so there is no guarantee that he will be allowed to stay. He may therefore be in the very difficult position of having put himself and his family at odds with the authorities in his home country.

I make these points because I had the experience earlier in the year of discouraging a Hungarian fellow, who was with a visiting scientific group, from defecting. People with whom he made contact in my electorate came to see me about the possibility of enabling him to stay in Australia. I advised them that there was no way that any guarantees could be given and that for his own sake and the sake of his family, he ought to be encouraged to return and to put in an application in the normal way, knowing full well the great difficulties he would face when such an ordinary application was processed. Nevertheless, I did not feel it would represent a responsible attitude on my part to encourage him to defect when even I, as a member of parliament, was not in a position to give him the guarantees he would require.

I think we would be better served if these groups concentrated on trying to improve the processes by which we facilitate ordinary family reunions between people in these countries and in Australia rather than seeking to encourage them to defect in this way. It would be a different situation if, for example, someone jumped across the Berlin Wall and we just had to do something with that person and resettle him somewhere else. I think that when people are in Australia on visitor's visas, in a sense as guests of Australia, it does not do us or the individuals any good if people in Australia take it upon themselves to entice them to defect and seek refugee status in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity provided at this late hour to draw the attention of the House to the problems now being faced by the Australian almond industry, which is under dire threat of being swamped by the large scale dumping of United States product in this country. Dumping will take place over our market, and then when Australian producers have been devastated a price hike will be imposed. The situation is an urgent one and yet the Government procrastinates. A Temporary Assistance Authority hearing was held in Melbourne some five weeks ago, on 17 September. The inquiry was expedited to enable the industry to meet the anticipated inflow of American almond kernels being sold at a depressed price, chiefly owing to the collapse of America's European markets as a result of currency changes.

SPEECH.PARA: We gather that this TAA report was with the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) in the early days of this month. Yet in spite of the immediate threat to the Australian almond producers, the Government seems unable to reach a decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say armaments?

—Almond-a-l-m-o-n-d. I realise that at this late hour the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has trouble but I will spell it out for him. I am talking about almond production. I point out to the honourable member for Mackellar that almond production is no fly-by-night operation. It does not operate on the basis of a get-rich-quick activity. It is a long term proposition for the people involved. Trees take some five years to produce reasonable crops and another five years to reach full production. The productive life of the trees is 25 to 30 years. This is an industry which provides the sort of 'real' jobs the Government claims it wants to create.
—Nuts!

—I point out to the honourable member for Port Adelaide that in his far flung electorate he also has some almond growers. It is imperative that Australia produce its own requirements of almonds. Imported almonds, mainly Californian, have comprised 60 per cent of Australian consumption over the last five years. Australian production is as efficient and its quality superior to imported almonds. United States almond marketing is erratic. Rapid price and availability changes are common. Why should Australian producers suffer as a result? Processors, workers and consumers all gain from market stability. All lose from the United States invasion. The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) is very familiar with this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The limited protection afforded the almond industry has not been sufficient to avoid the instability emanating from the United States almond industry. A tariff of 12 per cent, previously 15 per cent, is levied on imported almonds. To encourage the sale of Australian almonds and in the hope of keeping prices lower for consumers a by-law operates allowing buyers of Australian almonds some duty free imports-presently one tonne of duty free almonds for each two tonne of Australian almonds. However, unlimited imports of duty paid almonds are still allowed during certain periods. Combined with the ability to store almonds over long periods this means that prices for Australian almonds are determined by the alternative cost of importing almonds from the United States. The present system is unworkable. In August 1980 United States almonds landed in Australia for supply over the following 12 months was approximately $4.40 per kilo, setting the price of 70 per cent of the 1981 crop for delivery from March 1981 to February 1982.

Dramatic changes to exchange and United States production rates caused the United States almond price into Australia to drop by $1 to $3.30 per kilo and since to around $2.70. The tariff component of this price is some 25c. Obviously it is insignificant compared with the price differential of $1.70 per kilo. Now most Australian almonds contracted at $4.40 per kilo are still not delivered as buyers are faced with large losses if they have to sell against the cheaper, imported almonds. The remaining 30 per cent of the Australian crop is unsaleable except at ruling United States prices which are below the cost of production. As I said at the outset, opportunist traders are bringing in cheap almonds by the shipload. The responsibility for resolving this situation lies clearly with the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). His answer to the question from the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman) the other day was unsatisfactory. I am sure the honourable member recognised that. This is an issue on which we must have immediate decisions if the almond growers are to escape their present problems. While Nixon has fiddled the almonds have got more than scorched and smoked. It has been over two months since the Department of Primary Industry was alerted to the problem. Every day which passes increases the damage to the Australian almond industry.
Friday, 30 October 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) without repeating in any way anything he said. I will add a little to it. Since the report of the Temporary Assistance Authority came down several new facts have emerged that perhaps the House might care to take into account. The first is that when the announcement of the TAA inquiry into the almond industry was made it seemed to me that the forecast American price to its agents in this country was lowered a certain amount as was the internal price of almonds in America. Some price rises have occurred since the TAA inquiry report came down. The Americans have allowed a price of $1.09 per lb-I ask honourable members to forgive me for not giving the price per kilogram-while shipments are coming in from America. But from December 1982 onwards the price of American almonds coming to Australia, once the period of maximum usage of almonds in October and November is finalised, will increase to about $1.48 per lb. No matter whether the mechanism of moving both prices down is designed to dodge any likelihood of a beneficial TAA inquiry, the Americans have obviously aimed to disrupt the marketing of almonds in this country by lowering the price for that period. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the concern that many Australians have about the Government's promises in the education field. This is felt by many thousands of Australians, parents, school and school councils as evidenced by the numbers of letters and representations that honourable members have received from those people. I received a letter recently from the Mordialloc-Chelsea High School, which is in my elecorate of Isaacs, which puts very succinctly many points with which the Australian Labor Party would not disagree. I will read the letter from the Mordialloc-Chelsea School Council. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Charles,

I am writing on behalf of the Mordialloc/Chelsea High School Council to express our concern regarding several aspects of tertiary education and the proposed amalgamation of several Colleges of Advanced Education.

The need for some sort of rationalisation of tertiary institutions is accepted but we are concerned at the insensitive approach which decrees that all proposed amalgamations must take place by the end of 1981. It appears that these forced amalgamations, within such a limited time span, will have several detrimental effects, including a reduction of approximately 1200 places from the 1980 enrolments.

Although most of the Colleges concerned are Teachers' Colleges and thus have some common goals, each one has its own unique features, such as the excellent Physical Education course at Rusden State College. Hasty moves to amalgamation without proper consultation may well result in Colleges not only losing their identities but the best aspects of the courses which they offer.

We are also extremely concerned at the introduction of fees for second and higher degree students, this will cause difficulties for teachers who wish to further their qualifications, as well as other students, and may well be the 'thin end of the wedge' leading to a reintroduction of fees for all tertiary courses which would limit access of middle and low income earners, mature age students, married women and single parents to tertiary education.

The proposed reductions in TEAS are already making difficulties for many students. It appears that we are moving towards a situation where tertiary education will again be only available to those who can afford it. Rather than reductions in TEAS the scheme should be extended so as to more fully meet the financial needs of students.

The letter is then signed off. It shows the concern of many schools throughout Australia, and the Labor Party would agree with everything in that letter. I believe that the amalgamation part of the education legislation was accepted by the Senate last night. From the Labor Party's point of view, we would be extending, not reducing the scheme, which is the Government's policy.

I turn to one other point. The reintroduction of tertiary fees for second degree students is, I believe, the thin edge of the wedge as the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) has mentioned in this House before on behalf of the Labor Party. There is no doubt that the reintroduction of fees for second degree people will create a bias against lower income people and married and single people who are unable to afford to continue with their education. Thus, in education institutions we will have a continuing majority of elite people who are the only ones who can afford to continue their studies and to take second and third degrees.

I implore the Government to look seriously at the education matters I have raised tonight and which the Mordialloc-Chelsea High School has brought to my attention so succinctly in its letter which I brought before the House this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say something about the question of industrial policy which is very much in the news at the moment. It was in fact raised earlier by the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) who mentioned a letter from Mr Joe Thompson of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia which of course conflicted with the proposals put forward by Mr Len Townsend of the opposing motor industry union who combined with General Motors-Holden's Ltd in order to put forward views on the restructuring of the motor manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that some of the propositions being put forward by certain sections of industry at the moment are not in the best interests of the long term success of manufacturing industry in Australia. Basically, what manufacturing in Australia needs is a very clear-cut indication of where it is going. That is the message I get as I visit an enormous number of manufacturing plants in Australia, and I do visit very many in my travels because I take a particular interest in this area. Manufacturing also requires encouragement to redirect its investment into areas which are well competitive with a relatavely modest level of tariff protection. Some of the industry associations are putting forward propositions which do not assist this argument. The Jackson report, the Crawford report, and the various proposals put forward by the Industries Assistance Commission and indeed, the Government's own manufacturing industry White Paper, all make the very clear proposition and, I think, absolutely supportable proposition, that there should be a gradual change in the policies on protection so that there is a gradual reduction in tariffs to a point where the investment in Australian industry in manufacturing moves over a period into areas which require less support from the Government either directly by way of bounty or through the consumer by way of increased tariffs and therefore higher prices to the consumer.

I am very concerned at the moment because we have two things happening: First of all, we have a very strong campaign by the Metal Trades Industry Association which is opposing the Government's reference to the IAC for a general review of tariffs and of assistance to industry. The other thing that is going on is an opposition by the motor manufacturing industry virtually to any change in the levels of protection in that industry. Both these campaigns run against the requirement for gradual change in manufacturing industry. Unfortunately, the MTIA is adopting a view which will hold up the gradual change and which will ultimately bring about disruptive change. Every time a proposal for gradual change comes up, certain people who feel threatened-I understand why they feel threatened; I talk to them every day-fight against that gradual change and in the very process of opposing gradual change they bring about the certainty of ultimate disruptive change. That is what is happening with the MTIA.

In motor manufacturing there is a similar problem. Instead of having a gradual adjustment in the direction of lower protection over the last 10 years the motor manufacturing has moved in the direction of higher protection and therefore to greater dependence on political decision-making and, therefore, to greater instability. The motor manufacturing industry has disadvantaged the remainder of manufacturing industry by bringing about a situation of greater political dependence. What it has to do, I think, is to bring about a situation whereby over a decade it is not dependent on quotas. I think that over a decade that could be achieved. If any industry in Australia is not, over the course of a decade, able to restructure itself to the point where it can exist on a tariff of, say, 30 per cent, that industry is subtracting from and not adding to economic growth in Australia. There are many industries in Australia which can exist quite happily with a tariff of up to 30 per cent. But if an industry cannot, over 10 years, get to a point where it can exist with a tariff of 30 per cent and without quotas and therefore without the politicians deciding what buyers will buy, that industry is subtracting from employment and subtracting from Australia's economic growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question I want to raise tonight is a matter which has been of some concern to Western Australians who have taken an interest in defence matters over a number of years. The question is the need in Western Australia for an additional patrol boat base on the north-west coast. It is a matter of some disappointment to us that in the various discussions which have occurred in this place and in the many statements which have been made on defence matters by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) this year, promises that had been made in this House and in public in previous years have not been repeated. As well, the financial support which one would expect to be included in the Budget or by an indication given by the Minister has not been forthcoming in the course of this year. Furthermore, the facility which we have regarded for some time as extremely important clearly is not going to proceed. The fact that it is not going to proceed is to the very great detriment of Western Australians in their coastal surveillance needs.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I became a member of this House I was a member of an appreciative audience of what was sometimes unkindly called the Defence Department's travelling circus when it visited Western Australia to present an explanation to the Western Australian population, as it did in the other States, of every aspect-procurement, force structure, and so on-of the operation and policy of the Department of Defence. During that conference I heard an extremely well presented argument put forward by one of the officers that dealt with the very considerable advantages that increased facilities for staging patrol boat operations presented in improving the access of various areas of our coastline to effective maritime surveillance. Theoretical scenario he set up was for a patrol boat base between two patrol boat bases a few thousand kilometres apart. It conformed almost exactly to what are effectively the geographic dimensions of a potential patrol boat base in the north-west of Western Australia between Fremantle and Darwin. The advantage gained for the couple of patrol boats currently operating in that area, in terms of effective areas covered and the amount of time available, was not a question of simply doubling the amount of coverage. The result was very much greater than that- something like a ten-fold increase in effective coverage. This senior defence department official was not so incautious as to necessarily apply that argument to the Western Australian situation. The Government has not proceeded with that facility during the course of this year and it has given no indication that it will in the future. This will be to our very great disadvantage.

This highlights just a small aspect of the problem that we have in Western Australia in persuading our cousins in the eastern States to take seriously the problems with which we are confronted on defence matters. We are the object of a considerable degree of tokenism; a considerable number of promises of the Blue Hills variety. We are the object also of surreptitious and scarsely to be mentioned Nullarbor lines. I see that my time has almost expired. I will seek opportunities to raise this matter and related matters on other occasions. I place on record now my concern to encourage those honourable members on both sides of the House who take an interest in defence matters to start to look at Western Australian needs as a matter of priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that almost weekly in the newspapers across Australia we read of plans for the development of major convention bureaus at one point or another in the nation but very few of these plans ever seem to come to fruition. I would like to discuss this tonight because the Australian Association of Convention Bureaus currently estimates that, the convention industry is worth more than $200m annually in Australia in terms of direct expenditure that is being generated by the delegates. That is a most significant figure. The reason that I bring up this particular matter tonight is that Miss Susan Hunt, the Director of the Brisbane Visitors and Convention Bureau Ltd, has just presented a more than excellent report justifying the establishment of a major convention centre in Brisbane. Indeed, this report could apply to any part of Australia. There is no doubt that a need is emerging for a major convention bureau somewhere in Australia in order to attract a greater share of this visitor market, the convention market.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that, without really trying, a city the size of Brisbane can have conventions annually worth something in the vicinity of $25m. Statistics have certainly shown a trend towards increases in the number of dual-purpose visits-that is, people who come on conventions and later have holidays in Australia. Brisbane has certainly been overlooked in regard to convention traffic. This is one of the reasons why this bureau is pushing for the establishment of such a facility. In 1980, for example, without really trying, 120 national conventions were staged in Brisbane, including 7 international conventions. Some 63,610 delegates attended those international meetings and the local meetings in Brisbane during 1980. I think the most important thing that comes out in this report is that the current per capita convention spending in Australia at the moment is $100 per day-that is, $100 per delegate per day for a convention.

The sad part about the whole thing is that although Australia is getting a very small percentage of this market, frankly, we do not have the facilities to cater for the big international conventions and that is where the real money is. What we really need is a convention centre that seats a minimum of 2,500 people; that has dining facilities for some 2,500 people; that has large trade display areas incorporating access for vehicles and heavy machinery; that has full media, postal and telex facilities, flexible room sizes, simultaneous translation facilities, audio visual projection capacity, hospitality units and so on.

I say this because I am sure that all honourable members in this chamber would be quite amazed at the amount of money that is spent by Australians, Australian interest groups and Australian companies going outside the nation to hold off-shore conventions. Of course, the money that they spend at those sorts of off-shore conventions is all tax deductible. Quite often we hear of the activities of major companies, such as the Ford company which holds its annual convention in Bali. I understand that the Pharmacy Guild of Australia will go to New Caledonia this year. Previously it has held conventions in such diverse places as Singapore and Honolulu. So the list goes on.

Of course, the taxpayers of Australia are subsidising these conventions. Unless we have the facility it is very hard for the Government to get to a situation where we can cancel that tax deductibility for off-shore conventions that perhaps are not fully legitimate. Certainly, some Australians will always have to go to these international conventions. But there must be a very real case to be able to stop domestic conventions being held off-shore. This really is the crux of the matter. We really must look at the possibility of establishing a convention facility of international standard not only to handle domestic conventions but also to attract international conventions to this country. We are ideally situated in this part of the world. The only country with which we have to complete at the moment is the Philippines where there is a more than an excellent convention facility in Manila. I sincerely hope that government authorities at all levels will look at the prospect of establishing a meaningful, real, practical and large convention centre. There is big money in it for Australia. There are big advantages in it also for the taxpayers of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak briefly on two subjects. Firstly, I wish to deal with the establishment of Norforce in northern Australia. I congratulate the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen), the Department of Defence and the officers who were involved in finally forming a force in northern Australia that is essentially qualified through its expertise. The northern Australian environment and way of life is eminently suitable for such a force. Norforce is little more than one unit but I hope its formation leads to two things: Firstly, that it is enlarged eventually to a task force and, secondly, that the attention of the people of Australia is drawn to the vulnerability of northern Australia and its northern waters.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter on which I would like to speak for a few minutes is one of equal danger but danger of a different kind. It concerns the danger to the way of life of all those people who live in non-metropolitan areas. As one goes further inland so much greater becomes the danger of a new philosophy that we are taking to extreme. I refer to the transfer of public facilities to free enterprise. I was going to say to private enterprise. I would not be on this side of the House unless I not only encouraged the private sector but also, where at all possible, attempted to hand over the conduct of this country and its facilities to the private sector. There are very great and continuing dangers for people in what I call non-profit areas. There are people who live in scattered communities and people who are in mining communities. I have said very often in this House that I do not know why God decided that he would put the great wealth of this nation in remote areas. I have not had a chance to discuss that with him yet. I guess that chance will come in about another 30 or 40 years. The situation of our wealth of course creates a great tyranny of distance, which is the cliche we use so often.

Let me enlarge on that a little. Apparently some people on the other side of the House have decided to fill in the evening and fill in themselves at the same time, so we have inevitable interruptions. Of course, they are not interested. We did not like it when members of the Labor Party were in power. They stripped us of just about everything that gave us any sort of way of life in remote areas. They took away the air subsidies; they took away the fuel subsidies. They stripped the people of the inland of just about everything that gave them a better way of life. So one can understand how they are confused. They do not understand what I am talking about. In fact, it is so late I am beginning to wonder whether I know what I am talking about.

The matter I want to accentuate here tonight is what can happen if free enterprise is taken to an extremity, particularly by a public utility. If it is providing a non-profit service to areas of sparse population there are real dangers for those communities. I refer, for example, to airlines. The Holcroft Report recommended that if an airline route is non-profitable an airline has the right to cease that service. If after six months a route is non-profitable it is likely that it will remain non-profitable.

Another matter that I want to raise relates to banks. When the great commercial banks of this country amalgamate many branches close down. This may not be of much importance to honourable members opposite but it is of tremendous importance to the people in country areas. The greater danger is that if the banks decide that they will do business in hundreds of millions of dollars, it will be a mere irritation for them to lend some poor old landowner in a remote area $100,000 to survive a drought.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Sunday a significant development will take place in my electorate with the opening of another 61 home units for aged persons. This will be undertaken under the auspices of the Grand Lodge of Western Australia. I pay tribute to that body for the work it has undertaken for aged people in Western Australia. It has provided low cost rental accommodation for aged persons for a number of years. It has established already 180 units for the aged in the metropolitan area of Perth. It has provided also 10 dual purpose units in each of three country locations and presently is undertaking similar work in other parts of the State. It has developed a substantial hostel and nursing home complex in another suburb of Perth, Lindwood. But the development which is being opened up on Sunday really breaks new ground. It is a new undertaking and involves a joint venture between the Western Australian State Housing Commission and the Grand Lodge. The two bodies have come together and pooled their resources to meet the common objective of providing high quality accommodation for aged persons but particularly for aged persons who normally would not have the financial resources to get into many church and charitable organisations' aged persons homes.

SPEECH.PARA: This arrangement really is unique and is attracting the interest of a number of other States throughout Australia already. It provides for the Grand Lodge and the State Housing Commission to come together to meet this common objective whereby the Grand Lodge makes available for development land which it holds in title in the metropolitan and country areas of the State or which it is able to acquire from relevant local government authorities through negotiation. The State Housing Commission, for its part, undertakes the provision of the units to the Commission's normal standards. The Grand Lodge, at its own expense, quite apart from providing the land, provides any additional facilities which are needed in these homes such as furniture, fittings and fixtures.

The Grand Lodge also accepts responsibility for the management of these units when they are completed. It can provide the kind of care and concern which can come only from an organisation such as this which has had great experience in providing this kind of accommodation for aged persons. Because these two bodies have made contributions to the provision of these homes, they decide who will go into the homes on the basis of three people coming off the Housing Commission list for every two people who come off the Grand Lodge waiting list. This means, basically, that this accommodation is being provided for those aged persons who really need it and who cannot afford the other kind of aged persons accommodation established by so many other bodies throughout Australia. So these 61 units of accommodation which will cost about $900,000 are a pacesetter for what I hope will be developments of a similar nature in other States of Australia.

I pay a special tribute to the Grand Lodge of Western Australia for the wonderful contribution it has made to the development of this complex. I pay a tribute also to the Western Australian State Housing Commission, which has shown a great deal of initiative and innovation in agreeing to come together with the Grand Lodge to provide what is really a unique joint venture between the Government and the community through the Grand Lodge. I take this opportunity to give my complete support to this project in my electorate. It is an electorate which has a very proud record of providing the best accommodation for aged persons of any electorate in Western Australia. I certainly want to wish all the residents of these homes a long and happy life in this new accommodation.

Senate's requested amendments-
No. 1-Pages 7 to 9, clause 18, leave out the clause.
No. 2-Pages 10 and 11, clause 21, leave out the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has considered the request of the Senate for the deletion of clauses 18 and 21 from the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981. The Government believes that these provisions should be enacted into law. It does not accept that the provisions relating to unemployment benefit should be used to protect trade unions against the effects of their actions. While the Government wishes to maintain the ability to provide special benefit in cases of hardship, it does not believe that it is fair to the Australian taxpayers that they should subsidise the cost of strikes in Australia through their social welfare system. I therefore make it absolutely clear that the Government intends to pursue this particular proposal. However, to pursue it by refusing the request would penalise over 200,000 unemployment and special beneficiaries. Increased payments to them would inevitably be delayed if the Government rejected requests and sent the Bill back to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has no intention of allowing vulnerable sections of the Australian community to suffer because of the failure of the Senate to accept one aspect of the Government's proposals. Accordingly, the Government will accept the requests but at the first available opportunity introduce fresh legislation containing the provisions which are being deleted pursuant to the request. This House will be asked to pass that legislation as soon as possible. The Government was very disappointed when it looked as though the Opposition in the Senate was going to force the Senate to adjourn without these Bills having been dealt with because that would have penalised those who were due for the higher payments which were due to start this Saturday.

As a result of the urging of Ministers, the Labor Opposition in the end was forced to consider the matters. I want to point out to the House that both this House and the Senate could have adjourned at their normal time if the Labor Opposition in the Senate had done what the Government originally asked and allowed the debate on these matters to continue after dinner. It was apparently the intention of the Labor Opposition at that time to allow those who benefited from this Bill to be denied those benefits for an indefinite period. Even though the hour is late, I am glad that the Labor Party in the Senate has seen that that would be quite unfair and unjust to the people concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Government's surrender is a recognition that it does not possess the authority in this Parliament to impose what we described yesterday as the use of the social security provisions to impose destitution on families in pursuit of industrial discipline. That was the whole purpose of the two amendments which were resisted. The Government now recognises that it does not possess the authority. The excuse for its immediate surrender was that it had to make payments on Saturday. That is a recognition of the Government's legislative incompetence. The Government introduced a Bill on Tuesday which sought to make payments on Saturday. If the Government cannot get its act together somewhat better than that then the Parliament deserves to treat it with the contempt that it does.

SPEECH.PARA: In future the Government should try to get its Bills into this House in time to allow this Parliament to discuss major issues properly. It is absolutely absurd to introduce a Bill on a Tuesday that intends to start making payments on a Saturday and then say: 'Well, we had to get it passed. We had to accept these things because on Saturday the payments have to be made'. It is an absurd way to deal with legislation.

I now turn to the second point made by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt). Let the Government introduce a new Bill with these clauses inserted. We will continue to oppose the use of the social welfare provisions in this way. I believe the Senate will continue to oppose them. If the Government wants a double dissolution on this issue we would welcome it at any time.
Amendments agreed to.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth and State Ministers of Health agreed in March 1980 to legalise the narcotic drug heroin for medical use; if so, has his attention been drawn to the fact that (a) an article in the 18 June 1981 issue of the New Zealand Journal of Medicine condemns the legalisation of heroin for medical use as not socially responsible, (b) both the Reports of the South Australian Royal Commission into the Non-Medical Use of Drugs and the Report of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs recommended that legalisation of heroin for medical use should not occur until clinical trials have shown that it is clearly more effective than presently available drugs in the treatment of pain and (c) the use of heroin in Australia for medical use other than in clinical trials, constitutes a breach of the United Nations Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs.
(2) In view of these claims will he undertake to defer current plans to legalise the drug to permit reconsideration and assessment.

(3) Will he also undertake to adhere to all recommendations referred to in part (1) by agreeing that heroin will not be re-introduced for medical use unless and until its superiority to other drugs has been clearly and objectively demonstrated by clinical trials.

(4) If these trials demonstrate that it should be legalised, will he undertake to provide special grants to the States to assist them to provide the level of security and administrative controls necessary to prevent the misuse of the drug.

(5) Will he subsidise the cost of the drug's supply by the States or, alternatively, list the drug as a pharmaceutical benefit so that its cost to patients will be shared by the patient and the Government, and in the case of pensioner patients, will be available free under the Pensioner Medical Service and ensure that in both cases, the drugs prescribed as a Pharmaceutical Benefit are restricted to terminal cancer patients under special authority prescription.

(6) Is it a fact that (a) the cost of this drug, if used in hospitals, will make it a burden on State budgets, (b) if used outside of hospitals on private prescriptions, only the wealthy will have access to it and (c) taking into account Australia's medication system, heroin should be a Pharmaceutical Benefit as is morphine, but with added restrictions on prescribing.
(7) Will he undertake to refer this matter to the next meeting of Ministers for Health as a matter of urgency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Health Minister's Conference, meeting on 23 May 1980, agreed to the use of heroin for the control of intractable pain in patients suffering terminal carcinoma, conditional upon suitable controls being implemented. It was further agreed that the Commonwealth should strictly control the single scource of supply.

(1) (a) I am aware of the Editorial in the issue of the New England Journal of Medicine, 18 June 1981 which suggests that, 'the legislation of heroin for medical use does not seem socially responsible'. To support this conclusion, the Editorial includes reference to a recent study (1) by the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, U.S.A. using heroin in post-operative patients with cancer. It is of interest that the study has been criticised in that country as not being applicable to the problem of pain control in the dying patient.

(1) (b), (c) and (2) With regard to the recommendations on the therapeutic use of heroin of recent inquiries, and Australia's international obligations concerning the use of heroin, the Prime Minister wrote to the State Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory on 14 August 1981 advising that it was now proposed to conduct a clinical investigation in Australia which would aim to clarify the value of heroin in the treatment of severe, intractable pain in patients suffering terminal carcinoma. This approach is consistent with Recommendation 153 in the report of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs.

(3), (4), (5) and (6) Should States agree to co-operate in a clinical trial then the Commonwealth would take steps to ensure that States were able to provide adequate controls to prevent the misuse of heroin. The precise method of control, within principles to be finally agreed, would, if heroin is made available following the consideration of all these matters, be for individual States and Territories within the structure of their own legislation. However bearing in mind the tight controls which have been discussed to date, listing in the Parmaceutical Benefits Schedule would not seem appropriate. I would draw attention to the fact that the Commonwealth provides substantial funds to States for hospital and health services, including pharmaceuticals, within the normal tax sharing or cost sharing arrangements.

(7) This matter is presently being dealt with on a government to government basis, however, Health Ministers will, of course, be consulted regarding the findings of the proposed clinical trial, either separately or meeting as the Australian Health Ministers' Conference.

(1) Kiako, R.F. et al, 'Analgesic and mood effects of heroin and morphine in cancer patients with postoperative pain', in, The New England Journal of Medicine, Vol. 304, No. 25 18 June 1981, pp. 1501-1505.

(2) 'Health Consequences of Marihuana Abuse: Recent Findings and the Therapeutic Uses of Marihuana and the Use of Heroin to reduce Pain', a report of the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, Ninety-Sixth Congress, Second Session, p. 35 (Washington, 1980).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What provisions are being made by the Commonwealth Institute of Health, in their study of Vietnam veterans, for (a) general examination of sperm and (b) peripheral blood chromosomal studies as indicators of the veterans' potential for siring abnormal children.
(2) If neither of these well-documented procedures are being carried out, what are the reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No provision has been made by the Commonwealth Institute of Health in its studies of Vietnam veterans for either general examination of sperm or peripheral blood chromosome studies.
(2) These investigations have not been included for the following reasons:
Although the technique is well established, it is complex, time consuming and the results are difficult to interpret. Semen analysis has no value for prediction of congenital abnormalities.

Whilst knowledge is incomplete, several factors are known to influence human sperm production adversely including physical abnormalities, genetic and auto-immune disease, itercurrent illness, fever or infection, cigarette smoking and exposure to certain noxious agents.

Although the procedures for these studies are also well established, results are again most difficult to interpret. Results vary according to geographical location and may be strongly affected by the subject's recent exposure to a wide variety of mutagenic insults capable of causing chromosomal damage such as the ultraviolet component of sunlight or exposure to noxious agents. Most importantly, peripheral blood chromosome studies have no value in prediction of congenital malformation.

It is of some relevance here to note the results of a recent study of peripheral blood chromosomes undertaken in Western Australia at the request of Vietnam Veterans who allegedly were suffering ill effects from exposure to Agent Orange (Marie T. Mulcahy, Medical Journal of Australia, November 15, 1980, page 573-4). These investigations found no significant differences in chromosomes between the self-selected subjects and a control group. The author concluded that 'cytogenetic examination of Vietnam Veterans, if undertaken now, is unlikely to yield positive evidence of chromosome damage'.
