QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were advertisements, placed by Rexona Pty Ltd for the toothpaste marketed under the name of AIM, endorsed or approved by his Department.
(2) What approval is necessary before such advertisements can normally be placed.
(3) To whom was the advertisement referred for consideration within his Department, and what were the results of this consideration.
(4) Was his Department aware at the time of the claim that the ingredient in AIM known as zinc citrate had been available previously, contrary to claims by Rexona.
(5) Is it a fact that zinc citrate in a dentrifice is the subject of a 1971 patent and that it has been available in the United Kingdom in a toothpaste called Gibbs SR since 1975.

(6) Was his Department aware at the time of processing the application for approval that clinical studies were performed at the Battelle Institute in West Germany comparing plaque growth inhibition of AIM and 3 leading Australian products with brushing with water only.
(7) Did Rexona state that these claims proved conclusively that AIM had a greater plaque growth inhibiting factor than the other toothpastes.

(8) Did his Department request further details of these studies; if so, (a) were the results of these studies made available to his Department, and (b) were the results conclusive, and do they confirm Rexona's claims.

(9) Did Rexona also claim that a number of researchers had confirmed the plaque inhibiting effects of zinc citrate; if so, can he say whether one of the researchers, Dr Maddy, of Cardiff, Wales has rejected this proposition, saying his paper did not substantiate Rexona's claims.
(10) What attempts were made by his Department to substantiate Rexona's claims.

(11) Have any Australian dentists expressed concern that dental patients might assume they had received more protection from AIM than was the case, and that they then might be inclined to relax other aspects of regular dental hygiene.
(12) Is it a fact that Rexona has allocated $4.3 million to their promotion campaign for AIM.
(13) In view of this amount of proposed expenditure, did his Department take every step possible to assure the veracity of Rexona's claims.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Television advertisements placed by Rexona Pty Ltd for the toothpaste marketed under the name of 'Aim' were approved by my Department, after discussion and amendment.

(2) Under the provisions of section 100 of the Broadcasting and Television Act the approval of the Commonwealth Director-General of Health is required for the advertising of goods for therapeutic use on radio and television. All other forms of advertising are the responsibility of the State health authorities.

(3) The advertisement was referred to the Health Advertising Section in the normal manner. Data to substantiate the claims were requested and commented on by the Australian Dental Standards Laboratory and the Dental Health Branch.
(4) No. My Department does not have access to details of commercial products sold in the United Kingdom.
(5) Yes. However this fact was only subsequently brought to the Department's attention by another company.
(8) Details of these studies were made available and showed that in statistical terms there was a significant difference in favour of 'Aim' in plaque regrowth inhibition.
(9) No. Dr Maddy's research paper was not included in the data submitted.
(11) I am aware that such opinions have subsequently been expressed by certain dental practitioners during legal proceedings recently reported in the press.
(12) and (13) The company's advertising budget is not known to the Department and, in any event, would not be a factor influencing any decision taken.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Electoral: Conduct and Administration of Elections

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his announcement on 2 December 1980 (Hansard, page 227) that he was examining the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the conduct and administration of elections, what aspects of the Act and of the conduct and administration of elections are subject to the review.

(2) Has advice from outside his Department been sought or received in relation to the review; if so, (a) from whom has advice been sought or received and (b) in relation to what specific matters has it been sought or received.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act which I announced on 2 December, 1980 is a thorough and wide ranging one, covering most aspects of the Act and which is yet to be completed.

(2) I have deliberately sought views and opinions from a wide range of individuals, forums and organisations. In addition, I have received many representations on electoral reform from members and senators, political parties and members of the public.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the training period for Commonwealth Meat Inspectors is 6 weeks.
(2) Are the requisite qualifications for State meat inspectors of similar duration and content.
(3) If not, what are the qualifications and requirements for people to work as meat inspectors in each of the States.
(4) Are there any moves to require all meat inspectors to have identical or similar qualifications.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The qualifications and training required for Commonwealth Meat Inspectors are a Certificate of Competency in Meat Inspection issued by a recognised institution such as a technical college operating under the supervision of the relevant State authority. Study for such training commonly extends as a part time study course over a period of two years.
(2) No. Queensland and Western Australia prescribe particular qualifications.
(3) Of the States and Territory employing meat inspectors, the following pre-employment qualifications are currently prescribed:
Queensland-The Queensland Agriculture College Associate Diploma in Stock and Meat Inspection or completion of the competitive entrance examination set by the Queensland Public Service Board.
New South Wales-Certificate of Competency in Meat Inspection from a recognised technical college.
Northern Territory-Certificate of Competency in Meat Inspection.
Victoria-Certificate of Competency in Meat Inspection.
Western Australia-Certificate of Competency in Meat Inspection and a recognised qualification in health inspection.
General entry standards, including medical fitness requirements, are prescribed by all States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are both Tip Top Abattoirs in northern Western Australia licensed as export abattoirs.
(2) What are the regulations governing the spacing of carcasses as they move along the processing line.
(3) How many Commonwealth meat inspectors are employed at these 2 abattoirs to enforce the regulations governing export abattoirs.

(4) Can he guarantee that all these regulations and particularly those referred to in part (2), (a) have been enforced since Tip Top gained an export licence for these abattoirs and (b) will be enforced in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no Tip Top Abattoirs in northern Western Australia licenced as export abattoirs. The only export abattoir registered in the name of Tip Top Meats is located at Wooroloo, which is approximately 50 km east of Perth.

(2) The Exports (Meat) Regulations require meat intended for export to be prepared under hygienic conditions. This requires that, whilst on the slaughter floor processing line, skinned parts of adjoining carcasses do not come into contact prior to the completion of health inspection. There are no more specific spacing regulations.

(3) There is a combined staff of 14 meat inspectors, comprising 7 employees of the Northam Shire Council and 7 Commonwealth employees, normally located at the Tip Top abattoirs. They work as an integrated team, to export standards, under the supervision of a Commonwealth veterinary officer.
(4) (a) & (b) Yes, with the qualifications that minor breaches of separation, which are not critical if dealt with appropriately, occur from time to time in the best of regulated abattoirs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1981 (Hansard, page 2569) Mr Morris asked me a question, without notice, concerning the light aircraft which is missing in South East Australia with four persons on board. I undertook to obtain a full report on the matter and make it available to the honourable gentleman.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Yes, the missing aircraft VH-CGL was fitted with a crash activated emergency location beacon.

Initially, signals were received intermittently which were thought could be beacon signals from the missing aircraft. However, on thorough investigation these signals were found to be interference from power lines.
All Departmental F28 aircraft are fitted with equipment which can be used in the search for ELB's. All Departmental Merlin, Aero Commander and Bonanza aircraft are fitted with search meters.
The Aero Commander fitted with search meter participated in the search on Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday, 23-26 October.

It was considered that, because of the mountainous and heavily timbered terrain in the search area, helicopters would be more effective in the visual search and these were the primary aircraft used. The Departmental Merlins and F28s are fast low-wing aircraft and therefore less suitable for visual search in the type of country in the search area than the helicopters and Cessnas hired for the purpose.

A photographic reconnaissance of the search area was carried out by a RAAF F111 on Tuesday, 27 October. Preliminary results have revealed a possible sighting of aircraft wreckage in the vicinity of Mt Terrible, 26km south-east of Eildon Township. This is being investigated by the Police helicopter. Seven helicopters and one fixed wing aircraft have continued searching both this morning and this afternoon.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Superannuation Liability of Statutory Authorities under the Minister for Industry and Commerce

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What statutory authorities under his aegis have liabilities to the Commonwealth by way of employer contributions for superannuation which have not been paid or which have not yet been determined.
(2) If these contributions have not been paid, what are the amounts involved and how and when is payment to be made.
(3) If the contributions have not yet been determined, when is the liability expected to be assessed and how is payment expected to be made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the honourable member to the reply to Question 1320 given by the Minister representing the Minister for Finance which appeared in the Hansard of 10 September 1981, pages 1265 to 1266.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Government produce a small pamphlet for the information of electors following the presentation of the Budget in August 1981 outlining in simple comparative graphs the (a) gross national product and gross domestic product, (b) overseas reserves and commitments, (c) percentages of GNP uses for (i) capital expenditure and (ii) running costs for, (A) foreign affairs and defence, (B) social security, (C) State grants, (D) concessions, grants and other incentives, rewards and services to industry, (E) non-military education and science, health, Aboriginal and migrant services, (F) the ABC and (G) information and publicity on government, (d) proportions of (i) federal, (ii) State and (iii) local government revenue derived from (A) each income tax bracket and the numbers of taxpayers in each, (B) excise, tariffs, sales tax and other indirect taxes, (C) the Commonwealth Bank, (D) other enterprises and (E) other sources, and (e) extent of (i) overseas and (ii) domestic lending, borrowing and interest payments to and by each level of government and government banks as a proportion of GNP or GDP for (I) 1972-73, (II) 1975-76, (III) 1978-79 and (IV) 1981-82.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: While the Government welcomes efforts to enhance public understanding of economic matters and public administration, most of the information requested by the honourable member is available in tabular form in the Budget documents or other statistical sources or could be derived from those sources. The format of the Budget documentation has been developed over time in response to the needs of users. It would be possible to rearrange and publish the basic data in the manner suggested although this would obviously involve additional cost. The particular rearrangement requested by the honourable member is but one of many alternative presentations that could be adopted and the cost of acceding to all such requests would be prohibitive.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs: Language Needs of Departmental Personnel

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has any survey been made of the language needs of his Departmental personnel who are working overseas or in Australia with non-native/English speakers.
(2) What provisions are made to meet translation and interpreting needs when delegations are sent overseas or when overseas delegations are received in Australia.
(3) What preference is given in his Department's recruitment policy to persons with skills in languages other than English.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A survey was conducted in 1980 of all overseas missions to determine the foreign language proficiency requirement for every position to be staffed by an Australia-based officer. Within each mission, every position has been accorded a proficiency specification based on the functions of the position and the need for language proficiency to carry out those functions efficiently. Although there is some need for language proficiency for positions in Australia, this is mainly confined to staff of the passport offices. A survey has not been conducted on positions in Australia.

(2) Generally, Australian delegations visiting overseas are serviced by the facilities of the host country, although officers from a resident Australian mission can provide assistance. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs operates a translating and interpreting service for visiting delegations to Australia. When any Department is host to delegations from overseas, officers are selected from its own ranks who have the appropriate language proficiency to accompany the delegation.

(3) The Department does not give priority, as such, to the recruitment of staff who speak foreign languages. Experience has shown that given the wide range of skills and aptitudes required for service overseas, it is unlikely that a decision to recruit one applicant ahead of another would depend on language proficiency alone. While knowledge of a foreign language is an advantage, by itself it does not become the major determinant in a recruitment decision. Aptitude and motivation for language learning are tested after successful candidates enter the Department and on that basis selected officers are given special language training to meet Departmental needs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What makes of four-wheel drive vehicles are available in Australia.
(2) How many four-wheel drive vehicles have been registered in Australia in each of the years 1976-1981 and what proportion of total motor vehicle registrations does this constitute.
(3) What is the manufacturing or assembling capacity for four-wheel drive vehicles in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The term 'four-wheel drive' can embrace both passenger and truck type vehicles. Advice available to the Department of Industry and commerce suggests that demand for truck type vehicles having four-wheel drive capability is relatively small and generally confined to special purpose vehicles used mainly for off-highway applications. Readily available information relates only to passenger type vehicles and is given below.

(1) Motor vehicle statistics published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics do not separately identify registrations of four-wheel drive vehicles. However, industry statistics compiled by the private statistical organisation ADAPS indicate that the following brands of four-wheel drive passenger type vehicles were registered in the first half of 1981: Daihatsu; Datsun; Ford; Holden; International; Jeep; Leyland; Mitsubishi; Subaru; Suzuki; Toyota.

(2) As indicated in (1) official statistics are not available. The following table has been derived using data in the IAC Draft Report on 'Passenger Motor Vehicles and Components-Post 1984 Assistance Arrangements' and ADAPS statistics.
drive Total drive as % of Year

(3) Of the 11 manufacturers identified by product name in (1) above, Ford, Leyland and Jeep undertake four-wheel drive production in Australia. This production basically involves assembly from imported completely knocked down (CKD) packs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that pensioners in the Brisbane metropolitan area received pension cheques on Tuesday, 11 August 1981, the day before the Brisbaane Exhibition holiday.
(2) Were the cheques dated 13 August 1981.
(3) Is it also a fact that Commonwealth Bank branches displayed an instruction from the Reserve Bank of Australia to the effect that the cheques would not be cashed on 11 August 1981.

(4) Was there an occasion earlier in 1981 when pension cheques were posted to arrive in the Brisbane area before the due date when an industrial dispute threatened delivery; if so, on that occasion did the Reserve Bank accept and cash the cheques before the due date.
(5) What notification was sent to pensioners in the Brisbane area that their cheques would not be able to be cashed by the Commonwealth Bank prior to the due date.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Department of Social Security was informed that the Public Holiday in the Brisbane metropolitan area on 12 August 1981 and the backlog of mail caused by an industrial dispute could affect delivery of cheques. For this reason cheques were released to the Mail Exchange of Australia Post earlier than usual.
(2) Yes. Cheques were dated 13 August 1981-the payday.
(3) Officers of my department discussed this question with officers of the Commonwealth Bank and were advised that no policy directive was given for Branches to display such an instruction.
If such instruction were displayed, this action was taken at the initiative of local bank officers.

(4) Pension cheques for payday 30 July 1981 were released to the Mail Exchange earlier than usual to ensure industrial disputation did not affect timely delivery. The Reserve Bank of Australia has advised that it does not accept and cash cheques before the due date.

(5) Time factors did not allow for the processes necessary to send a notification to each pensioner in the Brisbane area but a press release was issued before the 13 August payday to inform pensioners that they might receive their pension cheques one or two days before the usual date. There was no reference to the Commonwealth Bank in this release.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In preparing the answer to question No. 629 (Hansard 2 April 1981, page 1336) did he request the information provided from Amoco Australia.
(2) Was any attempt made to contact lessee dealers or any organisation representing their interests; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. The terms of question No. 629 did not call for dealers or their organisations to be contacted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Minister's answer to question No. 2465 (Hansard, 20 August 1981, page 664) about proposals to establish an Institute of Freshwater Studies in Australia, what are the reasons for the Minister's refusal to take action to set up such an Institute.

(2) With respect to the Commonwealth Government's expenditure on freshwater studies in the last 5 years (including those of CSIRO), (a) where has this expenditure been incurred (i.e. in what places/institutions), (b) what did the Australian Atomic Energy Agency spend its freshwater funds on and (c) how is this expenditure broken down.
(3) What sums relate to (a) basic research, (b) theoretical research, (c) monitoring or other measurements, e.g. of stream flows, pollution, etc.

(4) Of the countries which already have institutes of freshwater studies, is the Minister able to indicate the average rainfall of each country and the estimated proportion of land surface which is desert; if so, will he provide these figures for Australia.
(5) Does the Australian continent have more serious freshwater problems than temperate countries with high rainfall and no deserts such as Canada and Finland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) See answer to parts (3) and (4) of Question No. 820 (House of Representatives Hansard, 2 April 1981, page 1332).

(2) and (3) I refer the honourable member to the 1977 and 1979 editions of the Inventory of Water Resources Research in Australia published by my Department on behalf of the Australian Water Resources Council. This publication is currently being updated.
(4) and (5) My Department does not have sufficient information to evaluate water resources problems in other countries vis-a-vis the situation in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he state in his Budget speech that the prospect for the labour market in 1981-82 was for a slowing in employment growth (Hansard, 18 August 1981, page 62); if so, did he mean that unemployment can be expected to increase.
(2) Does the Budget propose that unemployment benefits for persons under 18 years of age will remain at $36 per week.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to the prediction by the Victorian Liberal Minister for Youth, Mr Dixon, of increasing rates of youth crime and a growing incidence of youth homelessness unless unemployment benefits were increased and the means test raised in the 1981-82 Federal Budget.

(4) If so, what is the reason for the Government's decision to abandon the Community Youth Support Scheme which will lead to thousands of young people presently assisted through the Scheme becoming unemployed.
(In substitution for the answer which appeared in Hansard, page 1937 of 13 October 1981.)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Statement No. 2 indicates that total employment is forecast to increase by about 2 per cent in 1981-82 which, while still a relatively strong rate, would be below the 2.6 per cent recorded in 1980-81 and the 2.4 per cent recorded in 1979-80. This forecast easing in the rate of employment growth, together with an assumed labour force participation rate similar to that evident in 1980-81, implies some rise in the level of unemployment over the course of 1981-82, although the average level for the year as a whole would be much the same as in 1980-81.

(4) The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs announced on 24 September that current CYSS projects will receive their current level of funds until 28 February 1982 and that the Scheme will continue after that date under new guidelines. These guidelines will have particular regard to the best means of assisting young people who live in areas where training and education opportunities are limited or who are not qualified to benefit from existing programs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Availability of Automatic and Semi-automatic Military Type Firearms

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What restrictions currently apply to the availability of automatic and semi-automatic military type firearms.
(2) Has the Government given consideration to placing further restrictions on the availability of these weapons; if so, what restrictions are to be imposed and what type of firearms will be affected.
(3) Will the Government give consideration to permitting specific exemptions to these restrictions for collectors of military memorabilia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the time of your question fully automatic military type firearms could be imported only for official purposes and, in special circumstances, for use in film and theatrical productions. Semi-automatic military type firearms could be imported provided they comply with the licensing requirements of the State or Territory into which they were imported. Imported firearms must also comply with safety requirements.

(2) and (3) From 3 September 1981 a further restriction has been placed on the importation of certain semi-automatic military type firearms which incorporate a pistol grip in their design or which incorporated a pistol grip in their design when originally manufactured. Such firearms may no longer be imported for civilian use or for private collections.
Fully automatic firearms are restricted as previously.
The further restriction follows a recommendation to the Commonwealth Government from the Australian Police Ministers' Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have figures been released which indicate that the rate of bankruptcy has been increasing from an average of 1900 per year prior to 1975, to 4979 in 1979-80; if so, has the rate of bankruptcy continued to increase to levels well above 5000 during 1980-81?
(2) Are the Government's economic policies, particularly on interest rates, having a catastrophic effect on the small business sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The annual report on the operation of the Bankruptcy Act contains statistics on the number of bankruptcies recorded in a financial year. The statistics disclosed in the annual reports for the relevant period (the report for 1980-81 is still being drafted) are as follows:

Note: (i) The figures in this table refer to petitions under Part IV and Part XI of the Bankruptcy Act: Part IV deals with ordinary bankruptcies and Part XI deals with bankruptcies of deceased estates. The figures do not cover Part X matters: Part X is concerned with private arrangements between a debtor and his creditors which do not involve the debtor becoming a bankrupt.

(ii) The term 'bankruptcy' is used to refer to a matter that has been the subject of a separate debtors petition, creditors petition or petition by a person administering the estate of a deceased person.

(2) The Government's economic policies are aimed at containing and reducing the rate of inflation and thereby promoting in the longer term the strong growth in activity which is now evident in the economy. The achievement of this central objective of the Government's economic policies will be of benefit to everyone in the community including small businesses. In pursuing these policies the Government recognises the particular difficulties which would be faced by small businesses in endeavouring to cope with the depressed economic activity levels which would inevitably follow a resurgence of inflation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Savings Bank Cheques Paid to Veterans

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Savings Bank will not accept cheques from the Department of Veterans' Affairs paid to veterans on a fortnightly basis.
(2) Will the Bank accept cheques from the Department on a quarterly basis.

(3) Have other savings banks adopted this policy in respect of cheques issued by the Department to veterans; if so, will the Minister ascertain the reason for this policy and request that it be changed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Veterans' Affairs is not aware of any instances where the Commonwealth Savings Bank has refused to accept cheques the Department has paid to veterans on a fortnightly basis.
(2) The Department does not issue cheques on a quarterly basis. There are two modes of payment for pensions and allowances. These are:
(b) twelve weekly by direct deposit to banks, building societies and credit unions.
(3) The Department is not aware of any instances where other savings banks have refused to accept cheques it paid to veterans.

Some pensioners have requested the Department to make direct deposits to banks, building societies and credit unions fortnightly in advance. Consideration has been given to these requests but, because of the substantial additional expenditure involved in doing this, no action has been taken during 1981-82.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many claims have been made for the 2 1/2 per cent depreciation allowance introduced for tourist accommodation in the 1979-80 Budget in each year since 21 August 1979.
(2) How many new tourist accommodation projects are estimated to have been commenced in each of the same years.
(3) What has been the total value of tourist accommodation projects commenced since 21 August 1979.
(4) What has been the total cost to the Government of the depreciation allowance since its inception.
(5) Has the depreciation allowance been a major incentive in encouraging developers to construct tourist accommodation in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation has informed me that no income tax statistics are available of the number of claims made for the 2 1/2 per cent depreciation allowance in respect of tourist accommodation.

(4) The Commissioner of Taxation has informed me that deductions for depreciation allowed in respect of tourist accommodation are not distinguished from other amounts of depreciation in the income tax statistics. However, the effect of the new allowances will be reflected in the statistics of purchases of depreciable assets and depreciation allowed for businesses classified in the industry groups 'hotels, motels, etc.' for individuals, partnerships and trusts and 'restaurants, hotels, clubs and personal services' for companies. The latest available statistics relate to the 1979-80 income year and cover only individuals, partnerships and trusts. Company income tax statistics for that income year, the first affected by the 2 1/2 per cent depreciation allowance for tourist accommodation, will not be available for some time. It is not, therefore, possible to measure the cost to the Government of the depreciation allowance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reported statements by the Secretary to the Treasury to the effect that the Government would do nothing to help small business; if so, is this an accurate statement of the Government's approach to small business.

(2) Will he (a) discuss with the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs complaints that small businesses could be disadvantaged by the corporate cannibalism permitted by the alleged emasculation of the Trade Practices Act and (b) work with the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to promote effective support and protection for small business.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of such a report. I am informed that the report quotes the remarks of the Secretary to the Treasury out of context. The present Government has introduced many policies and programs which are of benefit to small businesses. These include more liberal profit retention allowances for private companies, more generous provisions for superannuation deductions for the self-employed, the abolition of Commonwealth estate and gift duties, the development of management training materials for the small businessman, the investment allowance, increased depreciation allowances, industrial research and development grants and export incentives.

(2) (a) The amendments which have been made to Trade Practices legislation since the first Commonwealth Trade Practices Act was enacted have helped to strengthen the competitiveness of private enterprise. In particular the present Act now covers, in addition to monopolisation, other matters such as exclusive dealing and price discrimination where small businesses can be disadvantaged by the behaviour of larger corporations. If small businesses have complaints about the activities which are covered by the Act they should take these up with the Trade Practices Commission which is responsible for the enforcement of the Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact, in the light of the appalling level of brokerage firm collapses over recent years in Australia and the failure of his Government to bring in national legislation, that (a) legislation affecting brokerage firms is operative in both Queensland and recently Western Australia, (b) Queensland is considering revising its existing legislation, (c) both New South Wales and South Australia are in the process of implementing similar legislation, (d) Tasmania and the Northern Territory are considering the introduction of similar legislation, and (e) the Victorian Government has intimated that it will consider the introduction of similar legislation.

(2) Is it also a fact that because of his Government's failure to enact much needed national uniform legislation, and despite respective State legislation, this will create all the deficiencies and the ineffectiveness that has plagued corporate and security markets in Australia.

(3) In view of the fact that all States are forced to enact fragmentary legislation, will it be necessary for the Commonwealth Government to enact legislation in the Australian Capital Territory and the Territories, to avoid creating a refuge for brokerage firms or their agencies seeking to avoid the obligation imposed upon them by respective State legislation; if so, does he intend to bring in the necessary legislation to close this gap.
(4) How many Australian and overseas brokerage firms are carrying out intra-State or interstate business in Australia.

(5) Because of the lack of uniform legislation in Australia, (a) will the firms referred to in part (4) be forced to meet additional costs such as registration fees, stamp duty and other relevant costs and (b) will these costs of necessity be borne by policyholders; if so, and if additional costs are to be imposed as a result of his Government's failure to enact uniform legislation, what steps will he take to ensure that these costs are minimised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that certain States have enacted legislation providing for the regulation of insurance brokers and that other States may be contemplating the introduction of legislative controls over brokers.

(2, 3 and 5) Decisions by several States to introduce legislation for their own purposes do not of themselves constitute a justification for the enactment of such regulatory legislation by the Commonwealth. My statement in the House of 10 June 1981 set out the reasons why the Government does not believe a need has been established for such Commonwealth legislation. It should be within the capacity of the States concerned, in consultation with the industry, to avoid any serious difficulties of non-uniformity between individual State enactments. In my statement of 10 June I said that the Government would hope that any prospective legislation by the States will recognise the benefits of existing self-regulation arrangements in the broking industry and have regard to the advantages associated with uniformity in controls. I also indicated that the Government stands ready to assist wherever it may be able in achieving legislative uniformity.
(4) There are no relevant official statistics, although the number of insurance brokerage firms with significant operations across State borders is generally thought to be relatively small.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 876 (Hansard, 25 May 1978, page 2578) what steps have still to be taken before Australia ratifies International Labour Organisation Convention No. 107-Indigenous and Tribal Populations, 1957, which (a) has no application in Tasmania, (b) South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia on 17 February 1967, 16 March 1967, 12 May 1970 and 17 June 1973 respectively, agreed that Australia should ratify and (c) Queensland said on 18 May 1977 it had no objection to Australia proceeding to ratify (Hansard, 25 February 1981, page 219).
(2) When does he expect that the remaining steps will be taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) As the Honourable Member will appreciate indications from the States such as he refers to are not in themselves conclusive in these matters. My Department is continuing to examine Australian law and practice in detail. This involves consultations with State and Federal agencies.

Recently-some States-Queensland, New South Wales and Tasmania have indicated proposed changes to relevant laws. My Department is to make an examination of these laws when they are passed before providing advice on ratification of the Convention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the 10 most common surgical procedures in Australia by number for the last calendar year for which figures are available.
(2) For each procedure, how many were performed by (a) specialists and (b) general practitioners.

(3) If (a) appendectomy, (b) tubal ligation, (c) tonsillectomy, (d) hysterectomy and (e) cardiac by-pass are not in the list of the 10 most common procedures, will he provide similar information for each of these procedures to that requested in parts (1) and (2).

(4) Has his Department compared statistics for the procedures referred to in part (3) for (a) city and (b) country areas and for the different capital cities; if so, what are the relevant statistics; if not, what is the reason.
(5) Does his Department use these statistics for health care planning in any way; if so, how.
(6) How rapid is the provision of this information by the registered health funds.
(7) Are these figures published on a regular basis; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 10 most common procedures in Part 10 (Operations) of the Medical Benefits Schedule during 1980 were:

Tumour, cyst, ulcer or scar, cutaneous, sub-cutaneous or in mucous membrane, up to 3 centimetres in diameter, removal by surgical excision and suture or by cryosurgery using liquid nitrogen. (Item Nos 3219/3220.)

Keratoses, warts or similar lesions, treatment by electrosurgical destruction, cryosurgery, chemotherapy or surgical removal-each attendance (including associated consultation) at which the procedure is performed on not more than 5 lesions. (Item No. 3330.)
Joint, or other synovial cavity-aspiration, or injection into, or both of these services. (Item No. 8105.)
Uterus, curettage of, with or without dilatation, including curettage for incomplete miscarriage. (Item Nos 6460/6464.)
Skin and subcutaneous tissue or mucous membrane repair of recent wound of, other than on face or neck, small (not more than 7 centimetres long), superficial. (Item No. 3046.)
Intra-uterine contraceptive device, introduction of or removal of under general anaesthesia. (Item No. 6262.)
Sigmoidoscopic examination with or without biopsy. (Item No. 4354.)
Evacuation of the contents of the gravid uterus by curettage or suction curettage. (Item No. 6469.)

Keratoses, warts or similar lesions, treatment by electrosurgical destruction, cryosurgery, chemotherapy or surgical removal-each attendance (including associated consultation) at which the procedure is performed on more than 5 but not more that 10 lesions. (Item No. 3332.)
Sterilisation by transection, or resection of fallopian tubes, via abdominal or vaginal routes or via laparoscopy using diathermy or any other method. (Item Nos 6611/6612.)
(2) (a) and (b) The incidence of services listed in answer to part (1) is as follows:
(3) The incidence of these services is as follows:

(4) (a) and (b). The Department has not compared statistics for the above procedures in respect of city and country areas of Australia. It would be possible to carry out an analysis by grouping services according to the postcode of the practitioner who rendered each service on the basis that the postcode of the practitioner and patient were one and the same. Not only would this exercise be time consuming and costly but it also would be based on an assumption which could distort the figures.

(5) The figures cited in answers (1) to (3) were extracted from the Health Insurance Medical Statistical System. This system is used for budget estimating, fees reviews, costing of changes to the Medical Benefits Schedule and ad hoc exercises such as research projects and public requests for information.

(6) Line by line data on medical services for which medical benefits are paid are received regularly from all registered health insurance funds. The average time from payment of a claim by a fund to lodgment of data with the Department of Health is estimated to be of the order of six weeks.

(7) Figures in relation to individual medical services such as cited in answers (1) to (3) are not published regularly but are available on special request. A number of general tables on the incidence and cost of medical services are published each year in the Annual Report of the Director-General of Health. Specific information of the type referred to by the honourable member would, in general, be too voluminous for the Department to produce regularly in other than computer file or microfiche media.

Footnote 1: The tables in answers (2) and (3) relate to services processed during 1980 by the private health insurance organisations and the Department of Health direct billing system. The statistics represent approximately 93 per cent of services on which medical benefits were paid during 1980.

Footnote 2: Figures cited in the ''general practitioners'' segment of answers 2 and 3 may not be entirely accurate. For example an examination of the 219 cases of cardiac bypass surgery attributed to general practitioners in answer (3) shows that:-
(a) there appear to have been errors on the part of registered medical benefit funds in looking up or transcribing provider numbers;
(b) where there have been invalid or omitted provider numbers, these practitioners have been counted as general practitioners;
(c) there are some inaccuracies in the classification of medical practitioners as specialists or general practitioners.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 25 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the 1981-82 Budget, what percentage of all Commonwealth Government outlays is authorised (a) by the Appropriation Bills and the consequential Supply Bills submitted to the Parliament for enactment each year, (b) by permanent and special appropriations which are not submitted to the Parliament for annual enactment and (c) in some other form.
(2) What proportion of Commonwealth Government outlays has been authorised by permanent and special appropriations for each of the last 5 Budgets.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the honourable member's attention to the answer given by the former Minister for Finance on 19 February 1980 in reply to question on notice No. 4471 in which he outlined various conceptual difficulties involved in drawing comparisons between ''Outlays'' and ''Appropriations''.

As that answer indicated not all appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF) and Loan Fund are classified as Budget outlays. Some transactions deriving from annual and special appropriations are classified as ''financing transactions'' and are therefore not included in outlays. Conversely, not all Budget outlays involve appropriations of the CRF and Loan Fund; for example, some Trust Fund outlays have their origin in prior appropriations of the CRF which are offset when the transactions of the CRF and Trust Fund are consolidated.

I have had prepared, as set out below calculations which are intended to be of assistance for the honourable member's purposes but note that these must be interpreted having regard to the above comments and to the qualifications contained in the reply to question on notice No. 4471.
For part 1 of the question, the calculations show as a percentage of estimated 1981-82 Budget Sector outlays:

(a) Total estimated expenditure authorised by the Appropriation Bills, adjusted to include allowances for prospective wage and salary increases ($160 million) and to exclude the Advances to the Minister for Finance ($225 million);

(b) Total estimated expenditure from Special Appropriations, including expenditure from the Loan Fund ($444.35 million), adjusted to include allowance for prospective cost escalation in education grants ($20 million); and

(c) The residual component which reflects the conceptual differences (described in the answer to question No. 4471) between total Budget outlays and the sum of the various appropriations; this residual accordingly represents the net effects of the classification of certain Appropriations as financing transactions or offsets to receipts (not counted as outlays), offsets to outlays not reflected in appropriations, the effects of items being recorded on a gross basis in outlays and receipts calculations, but being netted for the determination of the required Appropriation from the CRF, timing differences between Appropriations to Trust Accounts and expenditures from those accounts and the like.

The estimate of total Commonwealth Budget Outlays used is that shown in Statement No. 3 of Budget Paper No. 1; a reconciliation between the outlays and appropriations of the CRF is contained in Table No. 1 of Budget Paper No. 4.

The calculations provided for part 2 of the honourable member's question are based on the amounts actually spent under Special Appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund and Loan Fund during the relevant year described as a percentage of total Budget outlays. The adjustment made to estimates in the response to 1(b) above for cost escalation is not applicable for actual expenditures, since the allowance made for that purpose is taken up to the necessary extent as actual expenditure.
On that basis the following are the calculations provided in response to the honourable member's question:
(1) (a) 29.4 per cent, (b) 71.1 per cent, (c) -0.5 per cent.

I should mention that the substantial increase above previous years' levels in the 1981-82 figure (71.1 per cent) for estimated expenditures from Special Appropriations and the Loan Fund as a percentage of total Budget outlays reflects changed arrangements introduced this year in relation to funding of health programs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that a major biotechnology consortium has been formed in past weeks in Japan by Sumitomo, Mitsubishi, Mitsui, Asahi and 10 other major corporations.

(2) Is it also a fact that in 1980 the USSR used biotechnology to produce more than 1,000,000 tonnes of animal foodstock made from waste wood, a figure which is expected to reach 4,000,000 tonnes by the end of 1981.

(3) What action is he taking to promote the development of large scale research and development in Australia before it is too late to take advantage of our capacity to produce feedstock (such as molasses) for biotechnology industries generally and to develop our own skills in plant genetics.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that a number of major Japanese firms have recently formed a group to study new developments in biotechnology. The firms include Sumitomo Chemical and Asahi Chemical. I believe that the Institute of Industrial Science and Technology of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry is also involved.
(2) My Department has no information on the animal foodstock production figures from the USSR for 1980 or the projected production for 1981. The technology, however, is widely known.

(3) The Government provides considerable support for research and development through grants to Australian universities and through such schemes as the Australian Research Grants Scheme. Funds are also available to firms to support biotechnology R&D through the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act.

CSIRO is supporting an extensive range of biotechnology programs. The CSIRO Executive has been considering a review it commissioned of the potential applications of biotechnology in Australia. This report will be made public in the near future.

In addition, the Government has taken the initiative to organise a major symposium on the commercial applications of genetic engineering. It will bring scientists and businessmen together to assess the likelihood of commercial opportunities for firms operating in Australia. The symposium will be held in Sydney between 18 and 20 November 1981. A number of prominent overseas experts will be in attendance.
